 1. THE ENERGY SECTOR AND THE POWER SUBSECTOR A. THE ENERGY SECTOR The Economic Setting 1.1 Uruguay is small in both area (176,320 sq. kilometers) and population (3.15 million) with a good level of socioeconomic development. Per capita income (US$3,910 in 1993) is above the Latin American average, and income distribution compares favorably with that of many developed countries. The population is mostly urban (87 percent) and well educated. 1.2 However, despite the legacy of prosperity in the early 1900s, Uruguay's economic performance over the past four decades has fallen short of its potential. This is largely because of insufficient savings and capital investment. There was good growth briefly in the late 1970s in the wake of strong foreign fund inflows, which were unfortunately more associated with external debt accumulation than equity investments. As a result, Uruguay underwent a wrenching recession in the 1980s when the foreign inflow was reversed and the country had to service massive interest obligations. Although domestic savings subsequently increased, gross fixed investment remained low. This has accelerated the erosion of Uruguay's capital stock, which has long been inadequately maintained, and has contributed to the pattern of recurrent low GDP growth. The latter averaged less than 1 % between 1988 and 1990, and then increased to 2.9% in 1991, 7.4% in 1992, fell to 1.5% in 1993, and grew to 4.2% in 1994. The high growth in 1992 was fueled by strong capital inflows that helped finance a significant expansion of consumption and imports, as well as demand pressures from Argentina and Brazil, which still persist. 1.3 A recent Bank study (Uruguay-Private Sector Assessment-Report No. 11648-UR, June 18, 1993) found that unreliable power supply, inadequate transport facilities, poor communications between major cities and generally unsatisfactory trade facilitation and logistics are undermining Uruguay's private sector development. The Government has set about to overcome these deficiencies, recognizing that their early mitigation would be particularly timely. Uruguay is well positioned to become a successful open economy. Implementation of the MERCOSUR agreement (a common market among Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay) could intensify Uruguay's economic links with its neighbors, to which it is already quite vulnerable. Nevertheless, on balance, increased access to the MERCOSUR market, which has a combined output of over US$500 billion and almost 200 million people, could become a constructive factor in Uruguay's future growth. This applies particularly to the expansion of the service sector, as well as the possibilities of exploitation of regional energy market prospects. To a considerable extent, the realization of this opportunity depends on making the country's power distribution system more reliable, especially in the light of the possible expanded trade opportunities within MERCOSUR.
 -2- Energy Resources 1.4 Uruguay's energy resources are limited, and the country has to rely on oil imports to cover a significant share (55%) of its energy requirements. Hydropower resources are, by and large, already used (88% of all possible hydropotential is utilized), and the remaining potential hydro capacity (12%) is not economic to develop at present fuel prices. Thus immediate power demand will need to be met by energy conservation, thermal installations, and eventual power exchange with neighboring countries. Over the last twenty years Uruguay has maintained adequate pricing for power and oil derivatives plus additional conservation measures, have reduced the percentage share of oil in its energy consumption. Electricity rates have been kept in line with cost-of-living adjustments, and are based on marginal cost principles. Energy Consumption 1.5 Total energy consumption in 1992 was 2,052,000 TOE (Tons of Oil Equivalent), resulting in 0.649 TOE per capita, an adequate level when compared with other countries at a similar stage of development. Total energy consumption has varied in accordance with economic growth. During the recession of 1980-85, it fell by 3.5% per year compared to a 3.7% per year decline for GDP, and in 1985-91, it grew 2.3% compared to a 3.4% growth in GDP. The energy demand is concentrated in few sectors with, residential representing 37% of total demand, followed by industrial 29%, transportation 27%, and agriculture with only 7%. Annex 1 shows the participation of each sector in total energy demand, as well as the participation of the different sources of energy to supply the demand. This annex shows the importance of oil imports in the Uruguayan economy. To be able to serve future energy requirements, Uruguay needs to develop a strategy of Energy Options. Such a study is under way, as described in para. 1.13 and in Annex 3. Energy Sector Organization 1.6 The Ministry of Industry, Energy and Mines (MIE) is responsible for long range planning, sector policy setting, and supervision of the state-controlled companies in the sector. At present the sector is monopolistic. The most important operating entities are the National Petroleum Company (Administraci6n Nacional de Combustibles, Alcohol y Portland - ANCAP) and the National Power Company (Administraci6n Nacional de Usinas y Trasmisiones Electricas - UTE). 1.7 The Government (with Bank support) is reorganizing the energy sector. Based on studies funded by Loan 3517-0-UR (Public Enterprise Reform Loan, PERL), the Government has created an Energy Technical Commission (Comisi6n Tecnica de Energfa - CTE) composed of representatives of the Ministers of Mines and Energy, Economy and the Director of the Planning and Budget Office (OPP) to give technical support to the Government on regulatory issues and on tariff setting. The Ministry of Mines and Energy, through the Direcci6n Nacional de Energfa (DNE) with the support of CTE, would enforce
 - 3 - regulation. A new regulatory system will be created to open sector activities to market forces where possible. Measures contemplated would include the transfer to the private sector of the gas distribution system of Montevideo, private participation in some areas of oil distribution, private investments in power generation to compete with UTE, and private in distribution of electricity to certain areas of the country. B. THE POWER SUBSECTOR Institutional Characteristics 1.8 UTE was established in 1912 as the sole entity responsible for power generation, transmission, and retail distribution of electricity in the country. The scope of UTE's services is prescribed in the National Electricity Law (NEL) and UTE's by-laws. The NEL establishes the general regulation of generation, distribution, exports and imports of electricity. In October 1991, law #16211 was enacted to allow the participation of private investors in generation activities, but their participation in the sector has been very small because of the lack of adequate and specific detailed regulation of the general principles defined in the law. The new regulatory system being implemented (see para. 1. 11) will address this issue. A Presidential Decree enacted on November 7, 1994, has removed from UTE all regulatory power it previously had. This Decree created the Energy Technical Commission (see para. 1.7), transferring to it the responsibilities of giving the adequate technical support to the Government in defining tariff levels and enforcing regulations. A new regulatory framework defining transparent regulations favoring competition in power generation is to be implemented shortly (see para. 1.12). 1.9 UTE is an autonomous public entity (its Board of Directors is appointed by the Government) reporting to the MIE. Its budget is approved by the Planning and Budget Office (OPP), which imposes ceilings on investments and expenditures. The Government auditing agency (Tribunal de Cuentas) is responsible for ensuring that UTE complies with budget and procurement legislation. 1.10 The only other entity that now operates in the power sector is the "Comisi6n Tecnica Mixta del Salto Grande (CTM). " CTM is a binational entity owned by the governments of Uruguay and Argentina in charge of the operation of the Salto Grande hydro power plant (1890 MW). CTM's board is composed of five Argentine and five Uruguayan members, all appointed by their respective governments. Power Subsector Reform 1.11 The Government is restructuring the sector in order to promote private investment in new generation plants, with the Government increasingly playing a subsidiary role in investments, while strengthening its regulatory functions in areas where a natural monopoly exists. These reforms intend to: (i) remove from UTE all responsibility for policy formulation, power planning, and regulatory functions; (ii) define a clear concession regime
 - 4 - for private sector investments in competitive power generation; and (iii) create a new regulatory system to balance protection of the public interest with the need for enterprise autonomy, including the setting of tariffs in accordance with clear rules for their calculation. 1.12 Studies prepared by consultants (under Loan 3517-0-UR - PERL), and reviewed by the Bank propose the aforementioned new arrangement for the power subsector: a competitive market for power generation. UTE would be separated into three business units (Generation, Transmission and Distribution) with different accounting systems and transparency of cost allocation among them. Larger consumers will be free to buy energy from any generator. Transmission access will be open. Annex 2 gives additional details on the new regulatory system. As a condition of negotiations of the proposed loan, the Government enacted a Presidential Decree (on November 7, 1994), removing from UTE all its regulatory power (see para. 1.8) and creating the Energy Technical Commission to give the technical support to the government in its regulatory actions. A new regulatory system was designed based on the aforementioned consultant studies and would be put in place as one condition of effectiveness of this Loan. In addition, the proposed project would support the implementation of these modifications in accordance with Bank policy for the sector, and would allow the dialogue with the Government on this issue to be maintained. Power Subsector Policies 1.13 Power subsector policies are defined by MIE as part of the overall energy policy of the Government. An energy options study under preparation and funded under Loan 3517-0- UR is intended to recommend an energy strategy with different scenarios for primary energy sources (natural gas, oil and coal) to generate future electricity requirements. It will also consider power exchange with Argentina and Brazil through existing and possible future interconnections (see Annex 3). It will be a strategy paper, not an investment plan. The consulting firm to carry out the study has already being selected. The Government has launched the study as a condition of negotiations of the proposed loan. When the Energy Options Study is completed, the Government and the Bank will jointly review its conclusions, in order to provide technical support to the Government on different strategies for incorporating the study results into the planning of future power sector development. Electricity Pricing 1.14 The National Electricity Law defines the tariff regime in Uruguay. It provides that tariffs be set on basis of a target rate of return (not lower than 6%) on a rate base consisting of average revalued net assets in operation plus a provision for working capital. The tariff structure also differentiates tariff levels to customers at different consumption levels and different voltage levels of supply to reflect the cost of supplying electricity to them. The present average tariff level is 8.9 US cents/kWh, which is equal to the long-range marginal cost (LRMC). The LRMC was calculated as part of an independent study (financed under the Fifth Power Project, Loan 1779-UR) completed in 1982 and recently updated by UTE. As part of the preparation of this project, a consultant assessed the results of the LRMC
 study and carried out an analysis of the taxation and subsidies included in electricity prices (see Annex 4). The conclusions of this Energy Pricing Study concerning the power sector are: (i) electricity prices are currently about equal to marginal costs; (ii) UTE has a competent staff able to deal with tariff questions and qualified to undertake marginal cost analyses; (iii) electricity tariffs are correctly structured according to costs, and subsidies are non-existent; (iv) the tariff system could be improved by incorporating a seasonality element to reflect higher energy costs during winter; (v) the tariff studies could be improved through the implementation of the conclusions of a load characteristics study under way; and (vi) the institutional reform under implementation should not jeopardize the current electricity pricing structure. 1.15 The conclusions and recommendations of the Energy Pricing Study were taken into account in the preparation of the project. The Decree creating the new institutional structure was drafted in consultation with the Bank, and the reforms will not jeopardize the current electricity pricing structure. During negotiations agreement was reached with UTE to include in the proposed project: (i) a load characteristics study in accordance with terms of reference (TOR) satisfactory to the Bank (see Attachment 1 to Annex 11), whose results would be included in future LRMC studies and would be the basis for UTE's demand side management actions; and (ii) a marginal cost tariff study to update previous estimates (utilizing the results of the load curve study; see para. 1. 17), aiming to analyze the effects of possible different costs of electricity during the different seasons of the year (see Attachment 1 to Annex 11). Demand Side Management 1.16 UTE offers a time-of-day metering system with different tariff levels to promote demand side management. This system was first offered in 1986 to larger consumers (above 100 MWh per month and contracted capacity over 200 kW), which amounts to around 17% of electricity consumption of the country. They were offered three different tariff levels depending on time of consumption (peak tariff, from 6 p.m. to 10 p.m., night tariff, from 12 a.m. to 7 a.m., and valley tariff, from 7 a.m. to 6 p.m. and from 10 p.m. to 12 a.m.). In 1992 this tariff system was extended to medium consumers (contracted capacity over 20 kW). More recently (in 1993), UTE implemented a two level time-of-day tariff scheme (peak and off-peak) for commercial and residential consumers. The Bank has been monitoring this implementation, which began with marginal cost studies (under Loan 1779- UR - Fifth Power Project), and continued with the acquisition of special meters (under Loan 2484-UR - Power Engineering Loan). This new system improves load management, which reduces peak loads and allows customers to benefit from lower off-peak tariffs. 1.17 The most basic objective of the aforementioned new time-of-day tariff system is to promote demand-side management by transferring load from peak to off-peak periods, thus improving energy efficiency. UTE is also conducting a load curve study (financed under Loan 3221-UR), aiming to obtain the daily load curve for different classes of consumers to guide additional actions for efficient use of electricity. The proposed project would finance
 - 6 - the continuation of this study to help UTE take the necessary actions to improve its load curve (para. 1.15). In addition, UTE would begin a program for more efficient use of electricity by its consumers. The proposed project would finance technical assistance (see para. 3.4) to help UTE prepare and implement a Demand-side Management Program based on the results of the load curve study, and including actions to improve electricity efficiency (see terms of reference in Attachment 1 to Annex 11). Together with the Energy Options Study (see para. 1.13), this will allow UTE to develop aii adequate Integrated Resource Planning System. During negotiations, it was agreed that UTE would implement a satisfactory Demand-side Management Program. The program would be submitted to the Bank six months after the conclusion of the load characteristics study, and would be based on its results. Power Market and Facilities 1.18 The degree of electrification in Uruguay is high (97%) compared to the average of 70% for Latin American countries. Historically, UTE has operated and maintained its generating facilities satisfactorily. The generating installed capacity (including the participation in Salto Grande) is 1823 MW, of which 1241 MW is hydroelectric and 582 MW thermoelectric. Since the oil crisis of 1973, the share of hydroelectric generation in the total has increased, and today represents about 90% of total generation in years of average hydrological conditions. 1.19 UTE's 500-kV transmission system is interconnected to the Salto Grande hydroplant. This has allowed UTE to sell electricity to the Argentine market, and consequently to take advantage of the competitive environment created by the new regulatory system in Argentina. During 1992 UTE sold 2,268 GWh to Argentina, resulting in net earnings of US$91.8 million; sales in 1993 were 1450 GWh, and net earnings, US$44.1 million. In addition to the commercial benefits, this interconnection has also shown the Uruguayan authorities the benefits of a modern regulatory framework (as it exists in Argentina), stimulating them to promote in Uruguay the modifications that are now underway (see para. 1.12). 1.20 The domestic power market in Uruguay has shown increasing electricity consumption, with annual growth of 5.7% over the past four years. Total sales of electricity in 1994 were 4655 Gwh. Montevideo concentrates 52.3% of the sales and the interior responds for 47.7%. Sales to residential customers represents 45.9% of total sales, while industrial represents 35.7%, commercial 15.9%, and the remaining 2.5% public lighting. Annex 5 shows consumption of electricity in Uruguay during the past twenty years. 1.21 Under Loan 1779-UR (Fifth Power Project), consultants developed satisfactory methodologies to forecast electricity demand based on trends and regression analysis techniques. Using these methodologies, UTE has prepared load demand forecasts (see Annex 5). The three main consumer categories -- residential, commercial and industrial -- were analyzed, assuming an expected population growth of 0.5% a year, the same rate as in the previous decade; the same coverage and historic growth for consumption per residential
 - 7- customer; and an annual GDP growth rate of 2 % for the period 1993-2004. The market study forecast sales growth from 4527 Gwh in 1993 to 6873 Gwh in 2003, an average annual increase of 4.26%, which is consistent with past experience and future expectations. The generation requirements were calculated considering that the improvements in the system would result in reduction of losses to 13.5% by the year 2000, yielding a growth rate of 3.6% in generation requirements. UTE has also estimated its future sales in the power spot market in Argentina (see Annex 6). The supply options are outlined in para. 1.29-1.32 below. Losses 1.22 Losses have been at high levels for decades in UTE's system (19% in 1993), due to technical and non-technical losses. The high technical losses are concentrated in the Montevideo area due to a heavily-loaded transmission system, very old distribution installations (some more than 60 years old), inadequate distribution voltage levels for the present load magnitude (6 kV as medium distribution voltage), and an inadequate low voltage ungrounded system. To address those issues, a Bank-financed study (under Loan 2484-UR - Power Engineering Loan) confirmed by an independent study, has recommended the complete renovation of the distribution system, including modification of the distribution voltage levels and transformation of the low voltage system to a neutral grounded one. The complete renovation would be accomplished in four phases of approximately five years each. The proposed loan would finance the first phase of this renovation. During the preparation of this project, and as part of the ongoing Power Modernization Project (Loan 3221-UR), UTE has considerably improved its procedures for maintenance of the distribution system, which is now adequate, resulting in reduction of service interruptions to an average of four hours compared to 16 hours previously. 1.23 The non-technical losses result from inadequate accounting of self consumption in UTE's own installations, inadequate commercial procedures, and theft of electricity (black losses). Under Loan 3221-UR (Power Modernization Project), UTE has modernized its commercial operations, reducing the period between meter reading and bill delivery from 45 days to 24 hours. UTE has also created a new Division (Servicio Tecnico Comercial) to be responsible for implementing a program to reduce non-technical losses. During preparation of the proposed project, UTE prepared and submitted to the Bank a satisfactory "Non- Technical Losses Reduction Program". This program will have four areas of action: (i) commercial procedures; (ii) metering control and policy; (iii) theft of energy and direct connections; and (iv) accounting for losses. During negotiations UTE agreed to carry out the "Non-Technical Losses Reduction Program", as detailed in the agreed Implementation Plan (see Attachment 3 to Annex 12). 1.24 The first area of the program for reduction of non-technical losses (commercial procedures) has already been implemented. It included the modification and modernization of all commercial procedures from metering to bill delivery. Under Loan 3221-UR, supported by a twinning agreement with Uni6n-Fenosa from Spain, UTE introduced a
 - 8- completely new commercial system, eliminating all previous procedures. Today a customer can have all commercial activities perforned by telephone. All meter recording is now performed with the help of portable computer equipment, which automatically indicates any meter-reading error, and reduces the time for issuing the bills. This new system has been operating successfully for more than a year. The results are impressive, and have helped change UTE's image to its customers and to the general public. 1.25 The second element of the program (metering problems) aims at auditing the metering facilities to detect meter malfunctions and theft of electricity by meter tampering. It also aims at creating within UTE a system for management and supervision of the quality of installed meters. A first sampling analysis of the problem was concluded in June 1993 by examining 3,824 consumer installations. This study will serve as the basis for the recommended actions which are to: (i) create a data bank containing all information on installed meters; (ii) create a routine system of replacement and checking of meters; (iii) inspect all customer metering installations; (iv) change adulterated or malfunctioning meters; (v) seal all metering installations to facilitate future inspections; (vi) carry out a public relations campaign to educate consumers; and (vii) create a permanent follow-up of the metering situation of the customers. A timetable for these actions is included in the proposed Plan of Action (see Attachment 3 to Annex 12). 1.26 The third area of the program (theft of energy and direct connections) aims to assess the areas in which consumers connect their houses to UTE's system directly without the company's consent. It will be initiated by a field metering campaign designed to estimate the amount of energy lost, and at the same time to identify the areas in which this problem is more concentrated. Subsequently, UTE will address the issue in selected areas by contacting the consumers to normalize their situation. It will be done gradually and with care due to security reasons, since the majority of the cases are expected to be in low-income neighborhoods. The agreed plan has details on the actions proposed and a timetable for their implementation. Besides direct connections, the program will address the creation of routine inspections for regular consumers to avoid by-passes and other forms of tampering. 1.27 The fourth part of the program (accounting for losses) aims to estimate losses adequately by different levels (generation, transmission and distribution) and to account for the internal consumption of the power plants and the self-consumption of other UTE installations. The agreed program covers: (i) a survey of the electricity metering situation in all existing UTE installations; (ii) accounting of the "internal consumption" in all power generating plants and of the "self-consumption" in all other UTE installations; (iii) creation of a satisfactory methodology and routine for calculation of losses; and (iv) follow-up on the evolution of losses in the system. 1.28 For intensive surveillance on the implementation of the Non-Technical Losses Reduction Program, agreement was reached during negotiations that UTE will hire a consultant to serve as supervisor of its implementation. The consultant would report to the
 - 9- Bank and to the UTE General Manager on the progress of the program, in accordance with terms of reference satisfactory to the Bank (see Attachment 1 to Annex 11). Power Balance 1.29 Uruguay's current generating capacity (considering 50% of Salto Grande) is 1836 MW, of which 1241 MW is hydroelectric and 595 MW oil-fired thermal plants. Hydrogeneration is supplied by three power plants in the Rio Negro (Gabriel Terra, Baygorria and Palmar) and by the Salto Grande binational hidroplant in the Rio Uruguay. Thermal generation is supplied by the Batlle y Ordoiiez steam plant (305 MW), La Tablada gas turbine plant (227 MW), and by two small gas turbines (BBC and Maldonado). 1.30 Investments in future generation will have to rely on thermal plants, since the economic hydroelectric potential is being used. The energy options study being developed will indicate the best fuel source to use in future plants (see para. 1.13). In addition, the rehabilitation of old hydroelectric plants should be pursued to extend their economic lives. UTE is, therefore, rehabilitating the Gabriel Terra hydroplant, financed under Loan 2622-UR (Power Plant Rehabilitation Project), and plans to rehabilitate the Baygorria hydroplant in the future. 1.31 Using computer simulation models for planning and operation of power systems (developed by consultants under Loan 2484-UR), UTE has prepared a satisfactory power balance study. Lessons from Bankwide Lending to the Power Subsector 1.33 The Bank has been involved in power subsector reform in several countries. Matters of a general nature, as well as specific aspects relative to reforms in Uruguay, have been analyzed using lessons drawn from Bank experience in implementation of recent power sector reforms in several countries in Latin America. The Bank is helping the Uruguayan Government to modify the regulatory framework of the power sector. The new structure will introduce a transparent regulatory system separating the past dual role of Government as operator and owner of the sole power utility in the country. Government will retain its responsibilities for setting objectives, articulating overall policies, coordinating sector development and regulation. Regulatory rules will define the procedures for reducing the level of Government involvement in operations and increasing the accountability of enterprise managers. It will also define entry and exit conditions for private power producers. The Bank's new policies for the power sector have been followed in the preparation of this project, which will permit a transfer to Uruguay of the experience the Bank has acquired in its involvement in others countries. Lessons from Previous Projects for the Power Subsector in Uruguay 1.34 The Bank has made eight loans to Uruguay's power subsector; the first six are fully disbursed and the projects satisfactorily completed. THE PROJECT Project Origin 3.1 The obsolescence of the underground distribution system of Montevideo was discussed between UTE and the Bank during the preparation of Loan 2484-UR (Power Engineering Loan), and consequently consultants studies funded by that loan analyzed the issue. In fact the power distribution system of Montevideo is very old (some parts are more than sixty years old) and requires modernization to reduce service interruptions and technical losses that hurt Uruguayan industry and service operations. The actual network topology is totally inadequate without circuit breakers in the 30-kV system, resulting in several substations going out of service when a fault occurs in one of them. The distribution voltage to the consumers is phase-to-phase, which can result in very dangerous situations since no neutral (ground) connection is offered. This scheme also increases technical losses due to lack of grounding. The studies performed under Loan 2484-UR recommended the complete renovation of the distribution system by changing the voltage levels from 220 Volts (phase- to-phase) to grounded 380/220 Volts and from 6 kV and 30 kV to a sole medium voltage of 22 kV. Due to its concern over the amount of the proposed investment, UTE undertook another similar study using different consultants (funded by a bilateral agreement with Sweden), which confirmed the recommendations of the previous study. UTE and the Government then asked the Bank to assist with project implementation. The project was identified by a Bank mission in December 1992, and was prepared by UTE's planning division based on the above mentioned studies and additional consultant studies requested by the Bank. It was appraised in May 1994. Rationale for Bank Involvement 3.2 Uruguay's power sector is going through a critical period of reforms, including the establishment of a new regulatory system, modernization of institutions and the promotion of private participation. The proposed project would allow the Bank to be instrumental in furthering these reforms and in providing the necessary assistance to implement them, profiting from the Bank world-wide experience in sector reforms. In addition, it would address the increasing obsolescence of Uruguay's capital stock and help overcome one of the greatest concerns raised by the productive sector in a recent Bank survey: power supply reliability. The proposed project is in line with the Bank's objective of enhancing Uruguayan productivity to improve economic competitiveness. The strategy envisaged combines: (a) maintaining Bank dialogue with the Government to help in the implementation of the new regulatory framework; and (b) helping the Government to increase the reliability of power distribution.

The Ministry of Industry, Energy, and Mines (MIE) is responsible for sector planning, policy setting, and for supervising the two state controlled companies in the sector: the National Power Company (Administraci6n Nacional de Usinas y Trasmisiones - UTE) and the National Petroleum Company (Administraci6n Nacional de Combustibles, Alcohol y Portland - ANCAP). Both companies operate national monopolies in each area, with a mix of activities in operation and regulation. There is no regulatory entity in the sector, and UTE and ANCAP fix the quality standards for supply of energy products and propose tariffs to the Government, although the Government is reforming the sector and a new Institutional Framework should be in place as a condition of effectiveness of this loan. 2. Power Sector Institutional Structure. UTE is the sole generation, transmission and distribution company in the country, with the exception of the binational entity CTM, which operates a 1890 MW hydroplant. UTE is an autonomous public entity governed by a Board of Directors appointed by the Government. UTE reports to the MIE, but its budget is approved by the Planning and Budget Office (OPP). The Government Auditing Agency (Tribunal de Cuentas) reviews budget allocation and procurement process, and also audits UTE's financial statements. UTE prepares the tariff increase studies and submits them to OPP, which drafts a Presidential Decree approving it. 3. Power Sector Reform Studies. The Government is reforming the power sector aiming at: (i) making the regulatory function independent of UTE; and (ii) promoting private investment in power generation. Under Loan 3517-0-UR, consultant studies were carried out and a final report was issued in October 1993 with an assessment of the existing institutional framework, proposal for a new institutional model, and draft of a Presidential Decree creating the new institutional system. 4. Proposed New Power Sector Institutional Framework. The proposed institutional framework has the following main characteristics: (a) Separation of Roles of the State: The state will be responsible for defining sector policies and for regulating the sector. All regulatory activities presently under UTE responsibility would be transferred to the Government. Additionally, UTE will be kept as a public utility, but competing with private investors in power generation.
 - 36 - (b) Role of the Private Sector: Private investors will be allowed to install new power generating units to compete with UTE in an open competitive market. Private investment in transmission and distribution in some areas of the country will also be allowed. (c) Energy Technical Commission: An Energy Technical Commission was created by decree on November 7, 1994. It will be composed of representatives of the Minister of Industry, Energy and Mines, the Minister of Economy and Finances, and the Director of the Planning and Budget Office. This new entity would be assisted by technical units to help the Government on regulatory issues in the sector and on setting tariffs. (d) Regulatory Body: The regulatory body would be the Ministry of Industry, Energy, and Mines, through the Direcci6n Nacional de Energfa. It would supervise the long-term free market between generators and distributors, regulate the short term market, and regulate the distribution of electricity including approving tariffs. (e) Sector Structure: The sector will be divided into three areas - generation, transmission and distribution. UTE would continue to be a government-owned power utility, but its transmission and distribution activities would be separated into business units. UTE will be subject to the same regulatory rules as private sector participants. (f) Generation: Competition will be introduce~d into the generation of electricity.  - 49 - ANNEX 6 URUGUAY Power Transmission and Distribution Project Power Balance 1. Existing Generation Facilities. Uruguay's present installed generating capacity (including participation in the Salto Grande binational hydroplant) is 1836 MW, of which 1241 MW is hydroelectric and 595 MW oil-fired thermoelectric. Hydrogeneration is supplied by three power plants in Rio Negro (Gabriel Terra, Baygorria, and El Palmar) and by Salto Grande. Gabriel Terra is an older plant commissioned in 1948 with 128 MW (four units of 32 MW), which is now under rehabilitation (financed under Loan 2622-UR), including a change in turbines and complete rewiring of the generators. Upon completion of these rehabilitation works (scheduled for 1997) the life of this power plant will be extended by an additional 30 years. Baygorria is also an old plant, commissioned in 1961, with 108 MW (three units of 36 MW), and is under normal operation. UTE plans to rehabilitate Baygorria after finishing the works in Gabriel Terra. El Palmar is a new plant commissioned in 1982 with 330 MW (three units of 110 MW) and with a good record of operation. 2. Uruguay has a very small hydro reservoir capacity. The only existing reservoir is Gabriel Terra, with capacity for storing the equivalent of 4.5 months of generation. Salto Grande has regulating storage capacity for only two weeks and therefore its generation strongly depends on the volume of water inflow. UTE has hydrological data going back 82 years. The hydrological conditions of these rivers are very erratic. During years of average water inflow the generating capacity in Rio Negro is around 2,600 GWh, and Uruguay's share in Salto Grande is around 3,800 Gwh in average years. However, during dry years the generating capacity is substantially reduced to 600 GWh in Rio Negro and to 800 GWh for the Salto Grande Uruguayan share. This forces UTE to have a thernal backup to be used only in dry years and even to face curtailments in very dry years. 3. UTE's thermal installations are concentrated in two sites: Batile Thermoplant and La Tablada Thermoplant. Batlle thermoplant has six units which have been installed in different years. Units No. 1 and No. 2 are already retired and therefore out of service. Units No. 3 and No. 4 (50 MW each, steam turbines, oil fired, burning fuel oil) were commissioned in 1954. These units, in addition to their age, have a very low efficiency (329 gr/kWh), and are therefore the last units to be dispatched. Unit No. 5 is an 88 MW unit commissioned in 1970 with a fuel consumption rate of 262 gr/kWh and a good operational record. Unit No. 6 is a 125 MW unit commissioned in 1975 with a fuel consumption of 260 gr/kWh and a good operational record. Both units 5 and 6 burn fuel oil. In 1992 a fire in this thermoplant affected these two units. UTE is therefore rehabilitating them. Unit No. 5 is back to normal
 - 50 - operation and unit No. 6 (the one most affected) is under repair and scheduled to be in operation by the end of 1994. La Tablada thermoplant is a brand new installation commissioned in 1992 with 227 MW (two units of 113.5 MW each) consisting of two industrial type gas turbines burning diesel oil with a consumption of 270 gr/kWh. In addition to these bigger installations UTE also has three small gas turbines (GE, 10 MW; BBC, 21 MW, and AA, 24 MW). 4. Planning for Generation Expansion. A generation development study through the year 2000 (prepared by independent consultants in March 1980, financed under Loan 1779- UR) has shown that none of the identified small hydro projects can compete with thernal plants. Therefore, future generation expansion in Uruguay should be based on thermnoplants. However, the future development of MERCOSUR opens up the possibility of energy exchange between Uruguay and Argentina through the already existing 500-kV transmission line to Salto Grande, as well as the possibility of importing natural gas from Argentina. There is also the prospect of electrical interconnection with Brazil through a possible 500-kV transmission line in the future. Annex 3 describes the Energy Options Study to be carried out by consultants as part of the preparation of this project. UTE has also contracted consultant studies (Southern Electric International, financed under a US Govermuent Grant, through the Trade Development Agency) to analyze the technical and economical feasibility for the next thermal generation expansion in the Montevideo area, including: (i) rehabilitation of the Battle thermal plant, modernizing it and modifying it to burn natural gas to be brought from Argentina; (ii) installation of additional capacity (121 MW) in La Tablada transforming it into a combined cycle plant; (iii) installation of a combined cycle new thermoplant (180 MW) in the area occupied by units 1 and 2 of Batlle plant; and (iv) installation of a new combined cycle thermoplant (360 MW) in Greenfield. 5. UTE has a hydro-thermal computer simulation model for planning of generation capacity developed by consultants under Loan 2484-UR. UTE has also a competent and well trained staff able to use this model to carry out simulation studies. UTE has therefore prepared an update of the planning studies which defines the least-cost expansion plan for the next ten years. The study recommends the installation of 127 MW in La Tablada in 1996 and 190 MW in Batlle in 1998. These units would be part of a modernization effort in both thermoplants to transform them into combined cycle plants burning natural gas, if this fuel is available, or oil derivatives otherwise. These studies were analyzed by the Bank and found to be satisfactory. UTE has decided to rely on private investments for future power generation. Based on studies already completed, an additional 120 MW in gas turbines (in 1996) will be installed by UTE only if the private sector does not show interest in it. Subsequently, UTE plans to call for tenders from investors interested in installing the 180- MW combined cycle plant in Batlle y Ordoniez as an Independent Power Producer (IPP) to sell its generation to UTTE. The Bank has reviewed these studies and found them satisfactory. Based on the studies performed, the Bank was assured that UTE's expansion plan represents the least- cost solution for the required system expansion. 2. The proposed project includes investments in two different areas: (i) transmission expansion to allow an adequate supply of electricity to an expanding market; and (ii) renovation of the distribution system in three areas in the city of Montevideo to improve reliability, reduce technical losses, and extend the life of the power system. It is difficult to separate accurately the benefits resulting from each of these investments from the general benefits resulting from the investment program. However, to avoid doubt, a conservative approach was utilized in the economic analysis of the project. Under this approach two different rate of return were calculated: first, the rate of return of the renovation of the distribution system of Montevideo; and second, the rate of return of the entire investment program for the period 1995-2003. 3. The internal rate of return of the renovation of the distribution system was computed as the discount rate equalizing the present value of the cost streams and benefits associated with it. The cost stream (in 1994 constant prices) comprises the capital cost of the renovation equipment and works (excluding taxes and duties) for the entire distribution system in Montevideo, the operational and maintenance costs and the upstream cost (generation and transmission) of energy supplied, for the condition with and without the

The benefits were measured by the consumer willingness to pay the unsupplied energy in the "without project" scenario calculated at its lower bound value as the cost of unsupplied energy at the current tariff. The amount of unsupplied energy was estimated as the unserved energy by the existing system due to its capacity limitations. This is a conservative estimate since the unserved energy due to service interruptions was not included. The proposed project would finance only the first phase of this renovation; however, no attempt was made to evaluate the economic rate of return of this separate part of the system because the renovation in question will, in fact, install a complete new system with different voltage levels. Therefore, the only justification to implement the first phase is as part of the renovation of the whole system.  - 110- ANNEX 15 URUGUAY Power Transmission and Distribution Project Environmental Aspects 1. General. UTE's Environmental study area is very new and was created as a condition of Loan 3221-UR. UTE's organization includes one Environment Unit (UGA-Unidad de Gesti6n Ambiental) reporting to the General Manager (responsible for preparing the Environmental studies for future installations, motivating the operational units to address environmental problems in operating facilities, and acting as a nucleus for the creation of adequate capability in the environmental field within the company) and operational environment units in each operating department (responsible for implementation in its area of the recommendations received from the Environment Unit). 2. UGA Training Program. The proposed project would finance a training program for UGA staff. This training program will focus on training each of UGA's staff in their respective areas of responsibility. It will include on-the-job training through agreements with other utilities with more experience on environment matters, university courses, and transfer of knowledge from individual consultants. 3. Environmental Assessment of UTE. Under Loan 3221-UR financing, UTE hired a consultant in accordance with TOR satisfactory to the Bank to make an assessment of the environmental situation of UTE's facilities, and recommendations on the organization, work program, and training needs of UTE's environmental area. The recommendations of the report cover: (i) organization of UGA, (ii) training for UGA staff, (iii) thernoplants, (iv) hydroplants, (v) transmission lines, and (vi) substations. The Bank reviewed these recommendations and agreed with UTE on a restructuring of UGA that took place in January 1995. Also benefiting from this proposed project UTE hired a consultant that prepared a satisfactory environmental analysis of UTE's planned transmission program. 4. The Bank would help UTE to strengthen its environmental unit. Based on the results of this assessment study, UTE has restructured the Environmental Unit covering its objectives, functions and organization, as well as procedures for incorporating environmental concerns in the sector. UTE also agreed to implement a training program on environmental subjects. 5. The Project. The proposed project consists in its major part of works for the renovation and substitution of existing facilities. The expansion of the 500 kV system will comprise the installation of transformers in already existing sub-stations. Therefore no environmental effect is foreseen. The modification of the 150-kV system will comprise change of equipment in already existing sub-stations, the installation of a compact substation (SF6 enclosed), and installation of underground cables connecting substations, therefore with no environmental effects. The modernization of the distribution network will consist of replacing old cables by new ones at the same site.

doc.abstracts: The Power Transmission and Distribution Project aims to improve the reliability of the electricity service at least cost and to promote the sustainability of the reforms recently implemented in the power sector by helping the National Power Company (UTE) to adapt to the new institutional framework. Project objectives include: 1) consolidating sector reforms; 2) consolidating UTE's institutional improvements; 3) improving power distribution reliability; 4) promoting more efficient use of energy; and 5) improving customer safety. This project will be the first part of a staged approach to modernize the Montevideo distribution network and it includes: 1) modification of 500-kV substations; 2) expansion of the 150-kV transmission system in Montevideo; 3) first phase of the renovation of the Montevideo distribution system including voltage change of the medium voltage system and of the low voltage system; 4) technical assistance; and 5) training.
